BE

As I say, that's a thesis and unproven. But the regularity with which EasyJet warns about fuel, and its relative cost per mile versus competitors, suggests there might be something in it.

So anyway ............

11:19 am
PM

(Patience, well you could start with easyjet threatening to fall out of the single EU aviation market)

PM

Sorry, go on Bryce

PM

(*Pharma, Patience)

11:19 am
BE

Actually, I could go on. But Barclays can go on for me.

BE

FY16 PBT guide: £490-£495m. The guidance range provided for FY16 of £490-£495m PBT compares to our forecast of £511m, and is 3-4% below Bloomberg consensus. The miss appears to be FX driven, with Q4 trading inline with our expectations (revenue per seat/RPS -9% ex-FX), although the yield performance does highlight a very tough late summer trading environment – given that in July easyJet had sold 65% of expected bookings at -7.5% RPS. The combination of Brexit, France and Turkey geopolitical disruptions, and overcapacity on Western Mediterranean routes, have all weighed on summer pricing.

BE

FY17: Q1 RPS to continue at Q4 levels? easyJet has sold 45% of seats for the first quarter, and is expecting RPS to be similar to Q4, i.e. -9%. This is not inconsistent with market expectations and commentary from peers. However, we believe it includes an assumption of better pricing from November and December, given easier comparables (Paris, Egypt disruption), and we understand that current pricing, in October, is clearly down double digit. It is a major question, not just for easyJet but across our European coverage, as to what extent the geopolitical disruption of the last year has been one-off and what is an appropriate level of ‘underlying’ demand to assume in the next 6-12 months.

11:19 am
BE

FY17 moving parts: FX headwinds, cost. easyJet is guiding for a ~£90m FX headwind on FY2017, almost entirely driven by the weak GBP/USD, which would offset about half of the unit fuel benefits (£200m). We believe this currency headwind is higher than most sell-side estimates. Meanwhile, ex-fuel unit costs are guided to be +1% in FY17. Mathematically, piecing together the moving parts, and assuming that the yield environment moderates next summer (some would disagree, but we do think the comparable gets very easy), would imply a range of £400-£450m PBT, vs our published estimate of £490m and other recent analyst estimates in the £450-£500m range.

BE

One-off costs excluded from guidance? The statement notes that the +1% ex-fuel unit cost guidance excludes four areas: sale and leaseback transactions, set-up of European AOC, changes to organisational structure and the ‘outcome of on-going union negotiations’. Some of these items look concerning (especially unions) and we would look for an update at the FY results in November – hopefully quantifying the potential impact of these cost items.

BE

Note, the market expected this update to be bleak.

11:20 am
BE

So while FY consensus is down 20%, it's at least partly in the price.

BE

RBC reckons 10% in the price.

BE

easyJet's Q4/September FY-end trading update suggests trading remains soft even as the UK consumer backdrop remained buoyant and before any actual (2019E?) UK EU
exit impacts. This bodes poorly for 2016/17 as we still see UK GDP deceleration risk combined with (yet further) compounding winter market (over)capacity. (We assess this
based on city-pairs.) We note that during the financial crisis, the UK consumer did not peak until well into it - in September 2008 - so lagged demand risk remains a concern to
us on a business where the UK delivers ~ 49% of revenues on 53% of the fleet.
Over the last 5 months BBG consensus median PBT has fallen 30% from £742m to £518m - with easyJet now seeing it 5% lower again at £490-495m for 2015/16E.
However, we think 2016/17E consensus is still optimistic. After such deterioration in just for a few months of summer trading, we think the compounding effects (into
further winter market oversupply) make it unlikely that PBT increases by ~4% (to £537m) as consensus envisages for 2016/17E, even with attempted cost mitigation actions
by the airline. If the Q1 unit revenue outlook persists over the rest of the year, then 16/17E PBT could be £420m-£430m, vs. RBCe £431m - some 20% below BBG consensus.
Though a lower tax rate will help, this would leave (at 1007p) EZJ shares on ~11x (for a 14-15% RoE) vs. Ryanair on ~10x (greater than 30% RoE) and (on BBG cons) Wizz Air on ~9x (with greater than 25% RoE). If the profits don’t lift, the on multiple compression this implies 8-10% further downside on the EZJ share price (on this basis alone).

11:21 am
BE

1996-2015 PBT margin at aggregate average is 9% and we see likely regression to mean underway in airlines that are lacking a USP (e.g. lowest fares/costs, highest
frequency, or best product). With many 'me too' copy-cats, we think easyJet's USP has been eroded and so margin regression looks more possible. At a 9% PBT margin the
shares would trade on ~12x YA PER - in line with the 10 year median, but above the 5 year historical median of ~10x.

BE

To see an upside trigger to the shares we find that easyJet needs to offer positive factors including:
(1) big picture exposure to GDP acceleration (not declaration);
(2) operate in a market backdrop of supply discipline not a Prisoners Dilemma Game-like land-grab for market share and profits (which seems to be leading to margin erosion);
(3) easyJet can show sustained unit cost improvements larger than the drop in unit revenues;
(4) the company can provide a constructive answer as to how it will profit from fleet (rather than seat gauge) growth which (necessarily) will have to be in more contested,
and largely non-UK markets more prone to ULCC competition and legacy in-house LCC 'block and tackle' responses;
(5) easyJet provides investor comfort that despite EBITDA pressures, ND/EBITDA (lease adjusted) will remain contained (and not rise) thus avoiding equity erosion in the
EV; and,
(6) the company can re-establish a competitive advantage (beyond Gatwick slots) and a deeper USP (even if it is simply focused on predictable, punctual frequent service).

BE

Is there a case to be made here that EasyJet's not particularly well run right now?

11:30 am
BE

Stifel incoming, who are buyers so see the bright side.

BE

Q1 LFL reflects weather: Dunelm’s Q1 IMS comes just three weeks after the
FY16 Final Results presentation that flagged the “dampening effect” of recent
hot weather. Total Q1 sales were £198.7m (-1.8% total, -3.8% LFL).
Consensus expectations (Bloomberg) were for a c.3% LFL decline. This
performance comes against the toughest comparative quarter of FY16 (+5.5%
LFL in Q1, vs. +2.5% for FY16 as a whole). Gross margins are estimated to be
broadly flat (in line with Stifel estimates).

BE

Management believes (based on weekly GfK data) that the business continues
to outperform the overall homewares market. Home delivery sales also
continue to grow strongly (+17.9% YoY, c.7% of total sales).

11:31 am
BE

(@doeswalk, Rick: fair enough. I was basing it solely on my own prejudices, but don't travel enough to build up a proper impression.)

BE

FY forecasts -1.5%: Q1 is the smallest sales quarter of the year. Q2
comparisons are much weaker (unseasonably warm weather pre-Xmas
affected Dunelm and the clothing retailers). Against a Q2 comp base of -0.8%
(underlying, sale-adjusted) LFL, we expect LFL sales growth to turn positive in
the second quarter, underpinned by continued strength in home delivery sales.
Reflecting rising investment (key infrastructure projects, management, store
refurbishments, IT and logistics) as much as weaker Q1 sales, we are
trimming our FY PBT forecast by 1.5% to £130m (50.5p EPS).

BE

Buying opportunity: The hottest September weather for over 100 years is not
an ideal sales environment for a predominantly out-of-town homewares
retailer, but this quarter’s weak quarter will become next year’s soft
comparative. FY14’s weather-affected Q1 -5.3% LFL was followed by +8.9%
LFL 12 months later. Any short-term share price weakness therefore should
represent an attractive opportunity to increase weightings in one of the sector’s
strongest cash generators, which is also well placed to reap the rewards of
growth initiatives in stores and e-commerce, in our view.

11:32 am
BE

In terms of pricing, I thought Dunelm was Primark-ish? Or Sports Direct-ish? Online ain't easy down there.

BE

RBC also ..........

BE

Despite Dunelm’s reliable and consistent space growth strategy, we have a cautious view on the shares given potential operating deleverage and as Dunelm is very exposed to the UK housing market which has started to stall. Furthermore, our concern is that online growth is currently margin dilutive (particularly furniture) and so it may prove difficult to grow sales via this channel in a profitable way. As such we view Dunelm’s cal. 17P/E of 16x as fairly full for estimated very low single-digit earnings growth in the coming year.

11:34 am
BE

And Canaccord .............

BE

This weak start to the year pushes the onus for delivering our FY17 LFL estimates onto
the subsequent three quarters. This said, the reported LFL comparatives do weaken
across the rest of the year however, and we reduced our FY17 LFL assumption to +2.0%
in the wake of the prelims last month. We are therefore leaving our forecasts unchanged
at this early stage of the year.
There remains significant opportunity to further consolidate its market leadership
position within the highly fragmented homewares market. This will be achieved through
channel optimisation in terms of both e-commerce and physical stores. In the online
channel, incremental range extensions can be offered over and above the in-store
offering, facilitated by improved website, warehousing, distribution and IT systems.
The push since 2014 to drive store LFL sales growth should further benefit from the new
format trials currently being undertaken in Nottingham and Sheffield. It remains too early
to be more definitive on the uplift to sales and gross margin that could result across the
UK store portfolio, but with refits currently predicated on around a 10% sales uplift, the
potential uplift is substantial.

BE

The shares are trading on a cal 16E PER of 16.5x, reducing to 14.9x for cal 17E, with
corresponding EV/EBITDA of 11.3x and 10.1x. The traditional premium to the sector has
narrowed in recent weeks, but remains justified in our view by the combination of organic
roll-out and prodigious cash generation. The latter should continue to translate into a
regular flow of capital returns to supplement the ordinary dividend stream.

BE

11:36 am
BE

● A rapid bounce-back following the EU Referendum: UK corporate updates and economic news flow have been very encouraging since the EU referendum result, and the retailers, in particular, have seen consumer confidence recover and little impact on trading (weather notwithstanding). 2017 GDP expectations have begun to edge back up already, and the market has performed strongly, with the FTSE 100 +11% from the pre-result close.

BE

● But a challenging year ahead for the retailers: Looking ahead, 2017 is set to be a challenging, but not disastrous, year for the General Retailers. We expect the early effects of Brexit to weigh on employment growth, and drive some inflationary pressure on household costs, such that we expect retail sales growth of flat to +1%. Elsewhere, we look for FX-led COGS inflation to be part-mitigated and part passed onto consumers in the form of price rises, while opex inflation should be limited, with pressure from NLW inflation and the online shift being partly offset by operating efficiencies, reduced volumes, and a generally benign outlook for rents/rates. However, as a result of this, we see underlying retail profits being down, with a mid-point of our base scenarios of -5% even assuming retailers can successfully mitigate the COGS headwind and offset some of the impact of NLW inflation. This compares to our bottom-up forecast of +5%.

BE

● Sector multiple looks generous: The General Retail sector is currently trading on 12.0x cal-17 PE, consistent with the long-run average PE over the last 15 years of 12.3x. However, given a challenging earnings outlook, political uncertainty, structural pressures (ostensibly the online shift), and returns metrics markedly worse than six years ago, this looks somewhat generous, in our view.

11:37 am
BE

● Key picks are focused on online and proven growth: Overall, we remain cautious and retain our preference for proven growth plays – principally beneficiaries of the online category shift, and those rolling-out profitable space growth of 5% or more. Our key picks are ASOS, B&M, AO World, and Lookers. We are increasingly wary of the mature retailers within the sector and, reflecting this, we downgrade our recommendations on M&S (Hold to Reduce), Dixons Carphone (Add to Hold), Next (Add to Hold), and Halfords (Hold to Reduce) today. In addition to M&S and Halfords, we would also continue to avoid Kingfisher and WH Smith.

PM

Our Favorite Themes & Trades
In a nutshell:
 “Peak liquidity": the era of excess liquidity is ending
 “Peak globalization”: the era of free trade, capital & labor mobility is ending
 “Peak inequality”: as electorates demanding “War on Inequality” via fiscal stimulus
 Peak liquidity + peak globalization + peak inequality = peak returns
 We are long stocks & commodities, short bonds; we expect slim returns from bonds
& stocks in coming quarters; but double-digit upside likely for “ZIRP losers” in 2017
 Positioning, policy & profits to deliver a 2016/17 “flip” from “deflation” to
“inflation”, from “ZIRP winners” to “ZIRP losers”, from Wall Street to Main Street
 Positioning…few positioned for it; Policy…peak liquidity, peak globalization, fiscal
stimulus; Profits…US consumer, China producer, inflation up

PM

Buy what central banks buy in 2016: Japan stocks, EU/UK credit, EM debt
 Buy what fiscal stimulates in 2017: commodities, small cap, Main St
 Buy what nobody else owns in 2016 & 2017: “inflation assets” such as Japan, UK,
banks, TIPS
 Tactical Fed hike trades: long banks/short govt bonds, long Italian equities/short
gold, long EU banks/short US utilities/REITs
 Risks: a. dovish central banks (e.g. Fed passes in Dec) induce tech bubble; b. Wall St.
systemic event = disorderly spike in bond yields (corroborated by lower financials,
wider credit spreads, gold

11:41 am

I do like his style!

PM

What Do You Do?
 Buy what fiscal stimulates in 2017: commodities, small cap, Main St over Wall St
(Chart 5), banks (S5BANKX) over capital markets (S4CAPM), real assets (collectibles,
real estate & commodities) over financial assets
 Buy what nobody else owns in 2016 & 2017: “inflation assets” such as Japanese
equities, UK equities, banks, TIPS and value stocks
 The skeptics can “barbell” the above by adding exposures to uber-tech for “growth”
& EM corporate debt for “yield”
 Sell “bond sensitives”: utilities, telcos, REITs, staples, high-dividend & low-volatility
strategies

GKN PLC (GKN:LSE): Last: 337.00, up 5.8 (+1.75%), High: 339.60, Low: 336.00, Volume: 2.20m

BE

........ instead, we have HSBC giving it a push.

BE

We believe the equity story for GKN is a straight-forward one. It has world-leading technology, is an important supplier to major OEMs in its core end markets, and structural growth drivers – such as globalisation, fuel efficiency and additive manufacturing – are apparent. This is compounded with the potential for the group to expand margins, improve earnings quality and thus enhance valuation multiples. We believe that the market is not fully factoring GKN’s potential in addition to its ability to supplement the underlying investment case with further acquisitions. We accept that the group’s pension liability is large, but believe this is manageable given the cash burden requirement within its cash generation ability.

BE

Only mentions of M&A in the note relate to stuff GKN has bought and might buy, rather than what might buy GKN.

11:48 am
PM

It's a proper push tho

BE

I was entertained by the idea that GKN's a simple equity story.

BE

11:50 am
BE

But I guess there are .... uh, different classes .... of investor.

BE

We believe that GKN is a well-managed, technology-led, high market share business. A clear strategy focused on sustainable growth and delivery of share-holder value is bearing fruit with new technology and the possibility of further acquisitions providing potential for enhanced returns.

BE

We value GKN using our proprietary 'Market-Assessed Cost of Capital' (MACC) methodology, based on a through-cycle CROIC assumption of 10.5% and a target MACC of 9.5%, arriving at a 395p fair value target price. This equates to an exit (2017e) PE of 12.5x and EV/EBITDA of 6.2x, implying a deep discount to UK peer multiples of 19.4x and 12.0x respectively, implying 22.0% upside and driving our Buy rating.

11:51 am
BE

GKN trades at a large valuation discount to its UK peer group. We have used our sector coverage universe for the purposes of relative valuation. All these peers are members of the FTSE100 or 250 UK Engineers index. Our target price of 395p for GKN implies an exit (2017e) PE multiple of 12.5x which is much lower than the average 2017e PE multiple for its peers of 19.4x. Similarly, the exit (2017e) EV/EBITDA multiple implied by our target price is 6.2x, compared to the 12.0x 2017e EV/EBITDA multiple for the peers.

BE

So there's that.

Britain’s shale gas industry has won a big victory after the government overturned local council objections to a fracking scheme in Lancashire.

Fracking could restart next year after Sajid Javid, communities secretary, gave the go-ahead to Cuadrilla Resources to use the controversial technique at the Preston New Road site after a public inquiry. However, it deferred a decision on a second project, at Roseacre, in the county.

Nottinghamshire councillors on Wednesday deferred until November a decision on an application for test drilling by iGas at a former Cold War missile site near Bassetlaw after a legal submission from Friends of the Earth. Any future fracking would require a second application.

BE

Although IGAS has not made a fraccing application in this case, should the exploration results be positive then it will likely make a planning application to frac at a later date. As a reminder Egdon Resources (EDR)# holds a 14.5% working interest in PEDL 140 where the proposal is located and is carried on these initial wells by Total (FP FP).

However, UK shale players could still be given a boost today as Sajid Javid, the Secretary of State for Communities and Local Government is due to decide on whether to approve Cuadrilla’s plans to frac in Lancashire. Unlike other applications this is the last step in the ruling process and a positive outcome here should kick off shale exploration in the UK by launching a multi-well fraccing programme at two sites in the Bowland basin, whilst also representing a major win for the industry.
